content: Edit transparency: I've just updated the validator name (and name only) on case 5.

Major update: made the leap from Gravity Tumbler a lot larger. It's barely a tumbling problem anymore now.

Ironically, that makes it sensitive to an entropy attack by someone who's familiar with the problem.  Opinions welcome as to whether or not (lotsa) more tests would be warranted.
Not a huge leap beyond Gravity Tumbler, but it's enough to make an interesting separate puzzle. I vote to approve.
This is the “more interesting” version of  “Gravity Tumbler” which can be found there: https://www.codingame.com/contributions/view/470ee2d6180bd41469770d13396894d8b61

Ack! I had approved the previous version, but now there's something fundamental that I don't get about this. I have had to revoke my approval. :-)

Let's look at Double-like...

4 = 1 0 0

0...
a = 1
b = 2
t = t + 0*1 = 0

0...
a = 3
b = 2
t = t + 0*2 = 0

1...
a = 3
b = 5
t = t + 1*3 = 3

So we tumble 3 times (odd), right? And yet, the expected output is w: 17, h: 5.

Help me out here.

You're right. I must have b0rked it pretty bad when re-mixing and matching the pieces.

From my vague memories and rereading of the stuff, that bitstream should probably be in hexadecimal, my solution code is wrong (but comes with the test case) and I'm not sure I'll get a chance to fix it before Saturday.

I'll mark the title as WIP and get back to it ASAP.

On the plus side, my current solution being wrong means I'll be able to put the input data back in the correct order. :D

Ok, I'm back in business.

Rewrote the simplistic solution (hah, couldn't find it again in my mess), updated input format, so it's solvable in normal conditions again. Sorry about the mess.

Also, sorry about this: hexadecimal (the current input format) is *not* Right. Octal would be Right. I'll likely rewrite it in octal. It'll be so much better in octal. If you're moderating this before I update again, make sure your code isn't that hard to convert to octal, because this  puzzle will most likely end up in octal.

In the meantime, plus sides for me:
* input format makes sense again
* the TID overheating part is dropped, because there's actually a nice and easy puzzle to be made out of it. Stay tuned.
And my solution passes! I have re-accepted the puzzle.
Maybe we should add a test where the final number of tumbles is a multiple of 2^64.
